title: Conference Submissions
text:
The Industry Studies Association invites researchers to submit abstracts for papers and organized panels to the 2026 Annual Conference, taking place June 3-5, 2026 at George Washington University in Washington, D.C.


Single Papers: Submit abstracts of up to 250 words through Microsoft’s Academic Conference Management Toolkit.
Organized Panels: Include a panel description plus individual paper abstracts (250 words each) or panelist listings with roles. Panels should feature unifying themes—such as shared methodologies across industries or diverse approaches to common challenges. Panels incorporating practitioners from industry, government, or organizations receive particular encouragement.



All submissions are handled through Microsoft CMT (Conference Management Toolkit), which is a separate website from the ISA site. You can create a CMT account using any email address—it will only be used for managing your conference submission and is not linked to your ISA website account. If you don’t already have a CMT account, you’ll be prompted to create one when you first visit the submission portal.
Submit Your Paper via Microsoft CMT




Submission Portal Opens: December 5, 2025
Submission Deadline: January 23, 2026
Decisions Announced: March 01, 2026




Submitters choose from:

Sustainable Innovation, Energy, and Mobility
Public Policy and Global Competitiveness
Health Care Systems, Biotechnology, and Pharmaceuticals
Innovation, Entrepreneurship, and AI-Driven Transformation
Labor Markets, Organizations, and the Future of Work
Operations, Supply Chain, and AI-Enhanced Industry 4.0
General Industry Studies




For submission-related questions, please contact the Conference Chair: John Paul Helveston, George Washington University, jph@gwu.edu

title: Awards
text: The Industry Studies Association recognizes outstanding industry studies scholars through five award programs. Recipients of these awards are honored during the awards luncheon at the Industry Studies Conference and invited to present their work as part of the conference program. Each award is accompanied by an honorarium which is divided between all authors of the paper.

title: Awards
text:
Dissertation Award
The goal of the award is to recognize and reward outstanding doctoral research in the area of industry studies. Candidates must have completed a doctoral dissertation in economics, management, engineering, political science, sociology, or in a related or interdisciplinary field in the previous year and a half. The award is accompanied by a $500 honorarium for first prize and a $250 honorarium for the runner up.
Learn more about the Dissertation Award

title: Awards
section: Babbage Best Paper in Industrial Innovation Policy
text:
Babbage Best Paper in Industrial Innovation Policy
This award is supported by generous funding from the Babbage International Policy Forum (UK), under the leadership of Prof Sir Mike Gregory, in order to recognize outstanding contributions to the field of industrial innovation policy and policymaking. Winning papers are expected to demonstrate deep engagement with the theoretical and practical elements of industrial innovation policy. Submitted papers should exhibit a substantial commitment to understanding the interplay between policy interventions and industrial dynamics to shed light on the challenges and opportunities for policymakers, industry stakeholders, and society. We encourage submissions that embrace a cross-disciplinary approach, drawing on diverse methodologies and perspectives across economics, science and technology, and management. Submissions that not only advance theoretical knowledge, but also offer insights and recommendations for policymakers and industry leaders are encouraged. The award includes a $750 honorarium for first prize and a $250 honorarium for the runner up.
Learn more about the Babbage Award

title: Awards
text:
Giarratani Rising Star Award
Early career scholars are invited to submit one paper to which they have made a significant contribution to be considered for the Giarratani Rising Star Award. This award recognizes the contributions of junior scholars through their industry-based research drawing on the best industry studies traditions of deep knowledge gained through significant personal investment in developing an understanding of the markets, firms and institutions of an industry. The award is accompanied by a $1,000 honorarium for first prize and a $500 honorarium for the runner up.
Learn more about the Giarratani Rising Star Award

title: Awards
section: Best Paper in Innovation and Entrepreneurship Award
text:
Best Paper in Innovation and Entrepreneurship Award
Each year the Industry Studies Association invites submissions for the annual Best Paper in Innovation and Entrepreneurship award. The goal of the award is to recognize and reward outstanding research in the area of innovation and entrepreneurship. Paper submissions to any of the research streams are eligible for this award. A submission does not have to be submitted to the Innovation and Entrepreneurship stream to be eligible for this award. Self-nominations are accepted. As with other work in the industry studies tradition, winning papers are expected to demonstrate significant personal investment in understanding the markets, firms, and institutions of an industry and will frequently involve the integration of direct observation through field based research with appropriate theory and analysis. The Industry Studies Association is dedicated to advancing academic research that is grounded in a deep knowledge of a particular industry or industries. The award includes a $500 honorarium for first prize and a $250 honorarium for the runner up.
Learn more about the Best Paper in Innovation and Entrepreneurship Award

title: Awards
section: Ralph Gomory Best Industry Studies Paper Award
text:
Ralph Gomory Best Industry Studies Paper Award
The Ralph Gomory Best Industry Studies Paper Award was established by the Industry Studies Association and named for Ralph Gomory, who as President of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, initiated and steadfastly supported the Industry Studies Program. With this award, the Association seeks to showcase excellent industry studies research published in the preceding year in a selection of eight top academic journals. Through this award, the ISA hopes to encourage more researchers to submit their industry studies research to a set of leading scholarly journals, while sensitizing editors to the value of research that explores the industry context deeply. As part of its mission, the ISA seeks to promote excellent industry studies research that builds relationships with practitioners to gain access to primary data, brings the contextual knowledge gathered in the field to bear on the formation of research questions, and research design, and uses that knowledge to guide data analysis, interpretations, and conclusions. The award is accompanied by a $1,000 honorarium for first prize and a $500 honorarium for the runner up.

Conference Overview
The Industry Studies Association invites researchers to submit abstracts for papers and organized panels to their 2026 Annual Conference. The event takes place June 3-5, 2026 at George Washington University in Washington, D.C.

title: “Industry, Innovation, and Policy in Uncertain Times”
text:
Conference Theme
“Industry, Innovation, and Policy in Uncertain Times” describes the contemporary landscape where businesses navigate technological disruption, geopolitical shifts, supply chain vulnerabilities, climate demands, and labor market changes. The theme emphasizes how innovation increasingly occurs within active and consequential policy environments. However, submissions addressing this theme are optional—any rigorous scholarship focusing on organizations and industry dynamics is welcome.

title: “Industry, Innovation, and Policy in Uncertain Times”
text:
Venue
George Washington University sits in the nation’s capital, positioned near the White House, Congress, federal agencies, and policy institutions. The location also provides access to Washington’s innovation ecosystem, featuring clusters in cybersecurity, defense and aerospace, data and AI ventures, global development, and healthcare policy.

title: Dissertation Award
text:
The ISA annually recognizes outstanding doctoral research in industry studies through a competitive award program. The goal of the award is to recognize and reward outstanding doctoral research in the area of industry studies.



First Prize: $500 honorarium
Runner-up Prize: $250 honorarium
Presentation: Winners present at the 2026 Annual Conference (June 3-5, Washington, D.C.)




Applicants must have:

Completed doctoral dissertations between August 1, 2024 and December 31, 2025
Defended their dissertation and received final approval by December 31, 2025
Fields: economics, management, engineering, political science, sociology, or related/interdisciplinary areas




Nominators (typically dissertation advisors) must submit:

Extended abstract (maximum 5 pages, 1.5 spacing, 11-point font, 1-inch margins)
Nominee’s current vita
Completed nomination form
Supporting nomination letter explaining award worthiness




Submission Deadline: January 16, 2026
Award recipients will be notified in spring 2026.



Direct applications are not accepted. Candidates require nomination by dissertation supervisors or committee members, though nominators need not have prior ISA affiliation.

title: About
text: In 1990, the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation began a program of sponsoring academic research on industries through research centers at major universities. Each of the earliest Sloan Industry Centers specialized in the analysis of a particular industry. Eventually, the Sloan program grew to include twenty-six centers spanning a broad set of traditional and emerging industries, and research interests also expanded to include cross-industry analysis. As program activities developed, the list of scholars engaged in related research expanded well beyond the industry centers to include over 1200 Sloan Industry Studies Affiliates. Encouraged by this growth and the very positive response of participants to annual industry studies conferences, the Industry Studies Association was established by Industry Studies Affiliates in order to promote the kind of scholarship that had become emblematic of the Sloan program. The Industry Studies Association was incorporated in October 2007, became tax exempt in September 2008 as a 501 (c) (3) organization, and began accepting general membership in April 2009.

title: About
text:
What is Industry Studies?
Scholars who pursue industry studies come from a wide variety of disciplines such as management, economics, engineering, industrial and labor relations, operations research, law, economic geography, and public policy. While this list is by no means comprehensive, it does suggest the very broad range of disciplines that find value in collaborating around industry studies research. Industry studies scholars may focus their attention on particular industries or occupations, or conduct cross-industry analysis. Across research interests and disciplines, industry studies scholars make the kind of personal investment of time that is necessary to learn about the market and firm institutions in the industry or industries they study. This kind of engagement, which includes close interaction with industry practitioners and often includes direct observation at the plant, firm, or establishment level, allows industry studies scholars to pursue academic research from a broad and deep basis of understanding about the subject of their analysis. Its effect is evident in the selection of research questions, the methodologies employed, the nature of related analysis, and/or the interpretation of findings.
Scholars committed to industry studies research have demonstrated that the results of industry research that is grounded in observation and integrated with theory and analysis can make important contributions not only to academic knowledge, but also to industry practice and public policy.

title: Giarratani Rising Star Award
text:
The Industry Studies Association offers annual recognition for emerging researchers through the Giarratani Rising Star Award.



First Prize: $1,000 honorarium
Runner-up Prize: $500 honorarium
Non-winning papers may still qualify for the regular conference program




Applicants must meet the following criteria:

Junior scholars no more than six years post-Ph.D.
At least one co-author who is an early career scholar
Papers cannot have been previously accepted for publication
Individual scholars may submit only one paper to the competition




The award committee assesses two main areas:

Evidence of significant personal investment in developing an understanding of the markets, firms and institutions within relevant industries
Demonstration of combining direct interaction and observation with appropriate theory and analysis




Candidates must complete three mandatory steps:

Submit via Microsoft’s Academic Conference Management Toolkit (CMT)
Upload an extended abstract and designate “Giarratani Rising Star Award” in the submission form
Register for the conference and confirm attendance by early March

Submission Deadline: January 16, 2026



Non-completion of any requirement results in automatic disqualification.
